conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light, creating a dark area on a surface behind the object. The size and position depend on the light source's position relative to the object.
Four shadows labeled A, B, C, and D are visible, each corresponding to an object above it.
When the light source moves backward, shadows will move forward on the ground due to the change in the angle of light incidence.
As the light source moves farther away, shadows will generally become larger and more elongated.
Shadow A, cast by a cylindrical object, will move forward and elongate, becoming larger and more stretched.
Shadow B, cast by a triangular object, will move forward and become larger, maintaining its triangular shape but stretching out.
Shadow C, cast by a rectangular object, will move forward and elongate, becoming larger and more rectangular.
Shadow D, cast by a paper plane, will move forward and become larger, maintaining its shape but stretching out.
Final answer: Shadows A, B, C, and D will move forward and become larger and more elongated as the light source moves backward.
